title: Architectural Model, "Renaissance Style Tempietto", 1782
inscribed:
Latin inscription including dedication to Pope Pius VI, and the date "MDCCLXXXII
A.P.R.M."

"HOC OPUS A DRO JHO
BAPTA RASIO CAPIIZS ASGE
RIS SACERO IMPROBO- TRIENI
EXACTI[…] ABORE PIOVI PONT

MAX E GERMANIA REDUCI DUM ANGUILARIÆ PER GIAMB TRANS
ATHESIUM VEHERI[…] FUIT OBLATUM TANTAQ SS PATRIS ANIMUM
ADMARE PERCULIT UT IPSUM TER BENEDICENS AUCTOREM SUUM QUOQ SPIRITUALIBUS CUMUCARAIT DONIS XIII KAL.JUL.A.B.G.N.M.D.CC.IXXXII."
provenance: 1970s: Eugene V. and Clare Thaw purchased from Adrian Ward-Jackson, London; 2013: acquired by Museum
dimensions: H x diam. 68.6 x 43.2 cm (27 x 17 in)
creditline: Gift of Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw
description: In the form of an Italian Renaissance hexagonal chapel with domed roof above two stories of windows within pediments on columns.
justification: This extraordinary model of a temple is close to many late Renaissance examples, but was executed in 1782, probably in Venice.&nbsp; It is dedicated to Pope Pius the VI, clearly as a special commission.&nbsp; The execution of the very sophisticated carved and veneered ivory on wood is of excellent skill and the proportions are those of the late sixteenth century. It carries out its hexagonal shape from the base up to the gallery and on to the drum that supports the dome, which has oculi windows.&nbsp; Made by both a great model maker who was possibly also an architect, this model sums up many treatises on architectural refinement of the Renaissance in its execution, shape and design.

tombstone.epitaph: Architectural Model, "Renaissance Style Tempietto", 1782. Ivory, wood. Gift of Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw. 2013-3-2.
